item.title: By: Evan Weinberg
item.dc:creator: Evan Weinberg
item.description:
In reply to <a href="/2015/10/29/crutches-and-exponents/#comment-411">lisahines</a>.
Hi Lisa,
Thanks for sharing the study - certainly news to me. I wonder if there is a connection between pushing students to abstract reasoning too early and the difficulty these students have later on in understanding what they are doing in mathematics. I see the need for the abstraction, but not necessarily when it occurs in the traditional school sequence as it exists now.

item.title: By: lisahines
item.dc:creator: lisahines
item.description: Thanks for that reminder - I feel the same way about crutches. Interestingly, I've heard of a few studies linking finger counting and number sense, like this one (http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/18387567). It seems that for all we do to stop kids from using the "crutches" like writing things out and finger counting, we might actually be crippling them.
item.content:encoded:
Thanks for that reminder – I feel the same way about crutches.
Interestingly, I’ve heard of a few studies linking finger counting and number sense, like this one (http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/18387567). It seems that for all we do to stop kids from using the “crutches” like writing things out and finger counting, we might actually be crippling them.
